Chat with an OpenAI model

Source: R/provider-openai.R
chat_openai.Rd

OpenAI provides a number of chat-based models, mostly under the ChatGPT brand. Note that a ChatGPT Plus membership does not grant access to the API. You will need to sign up for a developer account (and pay for it) at the developer platform.

Usage

chat_openai(
  system_prompt = NULL,
  base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1",
  api_key = openai_key(),
  model = NULL,
  params = NULL,
  seed = lifecycle::deprecated(),
  api_args = list(),
  echo = c("none", "output", "all")
)

models_openai(base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1", api_key = openai_key())

Arguments

system_prompt

A system prompt to set the behavior of the assistant.

base_url

The base URL to the endpoint; the default uses OpenAI.

api_key

API key to use for authentication.

You generally should not supply this directly, but instead set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable. The best place to set this is in .Renviron, which you can easily edit by calling usethis::edit_r_environ().

model

The model to use for the chat (defaults to "gpt-4o"). We regularly update the default, so we strongly recommend explicitly specifying a model for anything other than casual use. Use models_openai() to see all options.

params

Common model parameters, usually created by params().

seed

Optional integer seed that ChatGPT uses to try and make output more reproducible.

api_args

Named list of arbitrary extra arguments appended to the body of every chat API call. Combined with the body object generated by ellmer with modifyList().

echo

One of the following options:

  • none: don't emit any output (default when running in a function).

  • text: echo text output as it streams in (default when running at the console).

  • all: echo all input and output.

Note this only affects the chat() method.

Value

A Chat object.

See also

Other chatbots: chat_anthropic(), chat_aws_bedrock(), chat_azure_openai(), chat_cloudflare(), chat_cortex_analyst(), chat_databricks(), chat_deepseek(), chat_github(), chat_google_gemini(), chat_groq(), chat_huggingface(), chat_mistral(), chat_ollama(), chat_openrouter(), chat_perplexity()

Examples

chat <- chat_openai()
#> Using model = "gpt-4o".
chat$chat("
  What is the difference between a tibble and a data frame?
  Answer with a bulleted list
")
#> - **Printing**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Automatically prints a more concise and user-friendly 
#> display than data frames, which includes only the first few rows and 
#> the columns that fit on the screen, along with a column data type.
#>   - *Data frame*: Prints all rows and columns, which can be 
#> overwhelming for large datasets.
#> 
#> - **Subsetting**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Does not simplify to a vector when accessing a single 
#> column, preserving the tibble structure as much as possible.
#>   - *Data frame*: Can simplify to a vector when a single column is 
#> accessed.
#> 
#> - **Column Name Flexibility**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Can have non-standard column names (e.g., spaces, 
#> special characters) without issues, and will print warnings instead of
#> failing.
#>   - *Data frame*: More strict about column names and might run into 
#> issues with non-standard names.
#> 
#> - **Data Types**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Preserves list columns easily, allowing more complex 
#> data types as column elements.
#>   - *Data frame*: Can handle list columns, but it's less 
#> straightforward compared to tibbles.
#> 
#> - **Compatibility with Base R**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Part of the `tidyverse` suite and may not always be 
#> compatible with base R functions that expect a data frame structure.
#>   - *Data frame*: Fully compatible with base R functions and 
#> operations.
#> 
#> - **Row Names**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Does not support row names by default, favoring explicit
#> column representations instead.
#>   - *Data frame*: Supports row names, which can be useful but also 
#> lead to potential confusion.
#> 
#> - **Performance**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Optimized for modern R programming, potentially offering
#> better performance with certain operations, especially with 
#> non-standard data types.
#>   - *Data frame*: General-purpose and might not be as optimized for 
#> every specific use case. 
#> 
#> - **Error Handling**:  
#>   - *Tibble*: Generally provides more informative error messages that 
#> help in debugging.
#>   - *Data frame*: Error messages might be less informative in 
#> comparison.

chat$chat("Tell me three funny jokes about statisticians")
#> Sure, here are three light-hearted jokes about statisticians:
#> 
#> 1. **Golf Game:**
#>    - Why do statisticians love playing golf?
#>    - Because they are always trying to find the mean in every swing!
#> 
#> 2. **Language Barrier:**
#>    - How do you tell the difference between a statistician and a 
#> magician?
#>    - A magician pulls rabbits out of hats, while a statistician pulls 
#> habits out of rats!
#> 
#> 3. **Animal Study:**
#>    - Why did the statistician take his shoes off before walking 
#> through a field of cows?
#>    - Because he wanted to avoid stepping in any bias!
#> 
#> I hope these brought a smile to your face!
